function.name: fast
function.synopsis: Returns a hashed value of a string, and is hopefully pretty quick about it
function.note: Hashes are curently 9-10 characters long with this algorithm.
This is used primarily to create fixed-length, database-indexable hashes for quick url lookups.

This function automatically reverts to SHA1 (truncated to 10 characters) if JHash is not available, -HOWEVER- you should -NEVER- switch between using both.
This can be problematic if your production enviroment has JHash and your development environment does not. Eventually I will get around to writing a pure-perl JHash algorithm for use where C versions are not available.
On nix you should have no trouble installing JHash via: perl -MCPAN -e "install Digest::JHash" For Windows using ActivePerl, see the extras directory for a .ppd. To install it: cd to the directory containing the .ppd file and type: ppm install Digest-JHash.ppd

function.name: secure
function.synopsis: Returns a hashed value of a string, and is hopefully pretty hard to crack
function.note: Hashes are curently 64 characters long with this algorithm.
If the Digest::SHA module is not installed, a pure-perl version will be used instead. It is pretty slow, but fine for most purposes, since hash_secure is not used often.
If you are using the pure-perl SHA module, you should DEFINITELY have JHash installed, since hash::fast() is called quite often.
